signalslink:usageinfo-signalslink-title: SignalsLink - extension for the Signals mod
signalslink:block-handbooktext-blocksens:
The block sensor detects the presence of a block in the selected adjacent position and, based on its type or the input signal, provides information on its state or the filling of its slots at the output.
The blocks currently supported are:<\/font>
Anvil<\/strong> - if there is a sufficiently hot ingot for forging on the anvil, the Output is signal 1. Otherwise it sends signal 0.
Doors, gates, trapdoors<\/strong> - For doors and gates you need to monitor the block at ground level on the hinge side. If the block is open, the Output is signal 1, if it is closed, the Output is signal 0.
Chest or, in general, container or any blocks that have some inventory slots<\/strong> (e.g. fire pit, barrel, trough, etc.). The Output is a signal according to the input signal.
The input signal determines which slot is to be scanned.
Signals 1-14 determine slots 0-13. The output is information about the filling of the slot relative to the maximum stack capacity of the item in that slot, converted to a signal 0-15.
Signal 15 determines that the sensor should detect the total filling of all slots, e.g. of the entire chest.
Some other block not listed above<\/strong> - If there is nothing in the monitored space (it is air), the Output is signal 0. If there is water, the output is 2–fresh water or 3–salt water. If there is any other block, the Output is signal 1.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-entitysen:
The entity sensor detects the presence of entities (players, animals, wild animals or monsters) in the designated area and can provide information on their number, type or state at the outputs. The sensor requires charging with one or more Temporal Gears for its operation. The rate of consumption then depends on the size of the monitored area.
Inputs x, y, z<\/strong> determine the size of the monitored area in blocks.
On the Error<\/strong> output there is signal 1 if the sensor is depleted, otherwise 0.
Inputs Output 1 setting<\/strong> and Output 2 setting<\/strong> determine what information will be provided on outputs 1 and 2. On each output you can thus obtain different information, based on the settings of these inputs.
The options are:
1 - The output returns Count<\/strong>. The number of detected entities.
2 - The output returns Category<\/strong>. Bit flags of entity category 0–3: player, creature, animal, wild animal.
3 - The output returns Life state<\/strong>. All detected entities are: 1–dead, 2–alive or 15–mixed.
4 - The output returns Sex<\/strong>. All detected entities are: 1–male, 2–female or 15–mixed.
5 - The output returns Age<\/strong>. All detected entities are: 1–young, 2–adult or 15–mixed.
6 - The output returns Type<\/strong>. All detected entities are: 1–player, 2–animal, 3–wild animal, 4–creature or 15–mixed.
7 - The output returns Reproductive state<\/strong>. All detected entities are: 1–ready to mate, 2–pregnant, 3–lactating or 15–mixed.
8 - The output returns Reproductive state flags<\/strong>. Bit flags 0–2: ready to mate, pregnant, lactating.
9 - The output returns Minimum generation<\/strong>. The minimum detected generation is: 0–15. Present entities without a specified generation are ignored.
10 - The output returns Maximum generation<\/strong>. The maximum detected generation is: 0–15. Present entities without a specified generation are ignored.
11 - The output returns Minimum weight<\/strong>. The minimum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Present entities without a specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
12 - The output returns Maximum weight<\/strong>. The maximum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Present entities without a specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-managedch: The managed chute allows automated transport of items between different blocks.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-managedwa: The managed chute embedded in a wall allows automated transport of items between different blocks. It allows transporting items through walls, which can be very useful for hidden transport systems or for transporting items from a cellar or into a cellar without breaking the cool cellar environment, which is important for long-term food storage.
signalslink:usageinfo-signalslink-text:
SignalsLink<\/strong><\/font>
Extends the Signals<\/a> mod with additional components.

To monitor a block in the vicinity you can use the Block Sensor<\/a>.
If you need to monitor your herd of cattle, the Entity Sensor<\/a> is great for that.
If you want to automate some tasks, the Managed Chute<\/a> will serve you excellently, as it can transport items between blocks similarly to a chute, but you control it with signals and it gives you much greater control over what is being transported. Its variant, the Managed Chute built into a wall<\/a>, then allows transporting items through walls, which can be very useful for hidden transport systems or for transporting items from a cellar or into a cellar without breaking the cool cellar environment, important for long-term food preservation.
signalslink:usageinfo-paperconditions-te:
Some blocks from the SignalsLink<\/a> mod allow the use of paper conditions<\/strong>:
• Block Sensor<\/a>
• Managed Chute<\/a>
• Managed Chute built into a wall<\/a>
Paper conditions<\/font> Paper conditions<\/strong> are conditions written on parchment<\/a>. These conditions can be used to influence the behavior of a block, for example to control output signals or to filter items in chutes.
Conditions are written into blocks (paragraphs). Each block consists of one or more lines, with each line containing one condition. All conditions in one block<\/strong> are evaluated by applying the logical operator AND between them, and the result gives the final value of the entire block.
Individual blocks are separated by an empty line. The logical operator OR is then applied to the resulting values of the individual blocks. Evaluation of individual conditions in a block takes place in order from top to bottom, as the conditions are written on the paper. Evaluation of the blocks also takes place in the order in which the blocks are written on the paper. This means that as soon as some block evaluates to true, this result is returned to the calling block and evaluation does not continue with the next block. This is very important and you need to take it into account.

We distinguish several types of conditions:
game:plank-oak<\/strong> - It is evaluated whether the monitored item in the inventory or the monitored block is of the specified type, i.e. its code exactly matches the specified code. If so, the condition returns true.
game:plank-*<\/strong> - It is evaluated whether the monitored item or block is of the specified type, in any of its variants (marked with an asterisk). If so, the condition returns true.
@.*-plank-.*<\/strong> - The code of the monitored item or block is evaluated using this regular expression. If there is a match, the condition returns true.
attribute > 1<\/strong> - The value of an attribute of an item in the inventory or the monitored block is evaluated. Various comparison operators (greater/less/equal) can be used here. After evaluation, the result of the comparison (true/false) is returned.
attribute<\/strong> - If only the name of an attribute of an item is given in the condition, it is evaluated whether it has a value or not. That is, zero, NULL, empty string or false is evaluated as false. A non-zero value, string or true is evaluated as true.

The negation operator !<\/strong> can be applied to all conditions. For example, !game:plank-oak is evaluated as true if the monitored item or block is not exactly oak planks.
At the end of each block you can add an instruction to set the output signal, for example output 1<\/strong>, which specifies that if this block evaluates to true, signal 1 will be sent to the output. This only has meaning for the Block Sensor<\/a>, which allows you to set what signal will be sent to the output if some block or item matches the conditions specified in the block. For other blocks that allow the use of paper conditions, this instruction is ignored. Setting up conditions<\/font> You write the conditions on parchment<\/a>. Do not sign the parchment so that you can edit the text again.
You transfer the conditions into a block that supports it by right-clicking that block with this parchment. The conditions are thus stored in the block and you will see them in the info window when you look at the block.
To remove conditions from a block, take an empty parchment in your hand, crouch (shift key) and right-click that block with the empty parchment. This clears the conditions from the block.
If you want to copy the conditions from a block onto an empty parchment, right-click the block with an empty parchment without crouching.
And finally, a helper for finding out what code some block or item has and what attributes you have available to use in conditional expressions:
Take the item you are interested in into your hand, hold down the Ctrl key and right-click with this item on a block that supports paper conditions. The item code and its attributes available for paper conditions are stored in that block. You can now copy them onto an empty parchment as described above and freely edit them into blocks of conditions and use them to configure the block.
